HistoricEvent.Description: The Spartans, led by King Archidamus II, invade Attica during Archidamus war
Alexander becomes the master of the Persian Empire
Alexandria in Macedonian Egypt becomes the largest city of the world
Historical records show that Chinese astronomers observe the appearance of Halley's Comet
The construction of the first city wall of Chang'an begins
Rome, capital of the Roman Empire becomes the largest city of the world
Christianity comes to Egypt as a church is founded in Alexandria
The disciples of Jesus form communities after the Diaspora, especially in Damascus and Antioch
Romans built a wooden bridge across the Thames in the London area.
Paul of Tarsus journeys to Rome, but is shipwrecked at Malta.
In China, the first official reference to Buddhism is made.
Siege of Jerusalem: Titus surrounds the Jewish capital
Titus destroys the Jewish Temple in Jerusalem
A Roman squadron, sent by Agricola, explores the north of Scotland for the first time
The Great Pyramid of the Sun, the tallest pre-Columbian building in the Americas, is constructed in Teotihuacan.
Armenia becomes the first nation to accept Christianity as a state religion
The first church is built on the site of Vatican City, traditional place of Saint Peter's tomb.
Constantine I refounds Byzantium, renames it ''New Rome'' (future Constantinople), and moves the capital to there.
Constantinople, capital of Emperor Constantius II, becomes the largest city of the world
The Jin Dynasty ends in China and begins the Song Dynasty
The Song Dynasty ends and the Southern Qi Dynasty begins in southern China.
The first Chinese paper money is issued
The first Arab siege of Constantinople begins.
The first printed newspaper appears in Beijing, China.
Chang'an, the capital of Tang Dynasty China and the largest city in the ancient world, is destroyed.
Greenland is discovered by Erik the Red (the first known European contact with North America).
The oldest extant university, the University of Bologna, is founded.
Pope Urban II preaches the First Crusade at the Council of Clermont
Constantinople, capital of the Byzantine Empire, becomes the largest city of the world
The first stone of Paris's Notre Dame Cathedral is set by Pope Alexander III.
The first reference to the windmill in Europe is made by a Dean Herbert of East Anglia
The first European gold coins are minted in the Italian city of Florence, and are known as florins.
The oldest surviving bell in the clocks atop the dome of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome is built.
The first recorded outbreak of the Black Death occurs in the Chinese province of Hubei.
The first patent is issued by the Republic of Florence.
Beijing, capital of China, becomes the largest city in the world
The first witch hunts begin, in Switzerland.
Christopher Columbus becomes the first known European to set foot on the island of Hispaniola.
Vasco da Gama's fleet departs from Lisbon, beginning his expedition to India.
Portuguese navigator Pedro √Ålvarez Cabral officially discovers Brazil and claims the land for Portugal.
The ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, painted by Michelangelo Buonarroti, is exhibited to the public for the first time
The first contact of Japan with the West occurs when a Portuguese ship, blown off its course to China
The Japanese receive the first firearms from shipwrecked Portuguese.
Shanghai is fortified for the first time.
The oldest surviving violin (dated inside), known as the ''Charles IX'', is made in Cremona, in northern Italy.
Over 1,000 Huguenots are massacred by the ultra-Catholic Francis, marking the start of the First War of Religion in France
The first performance of Shakespeare's ''Julius Caesar'' at the Globe Theatre in London
At Whitehall Palace in London, the William Shakespeare tragedy ''Othello'' is presented for the first time.
Manuel Dias (Yang MaNuo), a Portuguese jesuit missionary introduces for the first time in China the telescope
The first African slaves are brought to Bermuda, an English colony
Captain Jope's ship brings the first Africans to what will later be called America.
The first synagogue of the New World, Kahal Zur Israel Synagogue, is founded in Recife by the Dutch.
The first known cheque (400 pounds) is written
Beginning of King William's War (1689-1697) which is the first of four North American Wars until 1763 between English and French colonists
Benjamin Franklin creates the Philadelphia Police Force - the first city-paid force.
The oldest existing English language newspaper in the world, ''The (Belfast) News Letter'', is founded in Ireland.
Captain James Cook becomes the first European explorer to cross the Antarctic Circle.
American Revolution: World's first submarine attack, in New York Harbor
The volcano Laki, in Iceland, begins an 8-month eruption which kills tens of thousands throughout Europe
Elisabeth Thible is the first woman to ride in a balloon, at Lyon, France
Mozart's opera ''The Marriage of Figaro'' premieres in Vienna.
Mont Blanc is climbed for the first time by Dr. Michael-Gabriel Paccard and Jacques Balmat.
War of the First Coalition - Battle of Lodi: General Napoleon Bonaparte defeats Austrian rearguard (River Adda, Italy)
The first census in Brazil counts 2 million blacks in a total population of 3.25 million.
George Washington, the first President of the United States, dies in Mount Vernon, Virginia.
Napoleon Bonaparte crosses the Alps and invades Italy.
At Notre Dame Cathedral in Paris, Napoleon Bonaparte crowns himself as the first Emperor of the French in a thousand years
Spain declares war on Britain.
The city of La Paz (current Bolivia) declares its independence from the Spanish Crown
May Revolution: Armed citizens of Buenos Aires expel the Viceroy from Spain and establish a provincial government for Argentina.
The Pernambucan Revolt breaks out in Brazil.
Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua and Costa Rica gain independence from Spain
The first group of freed slaves from the USA arrive in modern-day Liberia and found Monrovia
Brazil declares its independence from Portugal
The first horse-drawn omnibuses established in London.
The first railway tunnel is built en route between Liverpool and Manchester in England.
Brazil and Argentina recognize the independence of Uruguay
The first English newspaper is published in Hawaii.
Charles Darwin returns to Britain aboard the HMS ''Beagle'' with biological data he will later use to develop his Theory of evolution.
The first ever international cricket match is played in New York City
Anesthesia is used for childbirth for the first time, in Jefferson, Georgia
The Vegetarian Society was formed in the United Kingdom, the oldest in the world
The first Public Aquarium opens at the London Zoo.
The Panama Railway becomes the first railroad to connect the Atlantic Ocean and Pacific Ocean.
David Livingstone becomes the first European to see Victoria Falls in what is now present-day Zambia-Zimbabwe.
The first ship passes through the Suez Canal.
The first Trades Union Congress is held in Manchester, England
The first rugby match is played in New Zealand
Wabash, Indiana becomes the first electrically lit city in the world.
Construction of the foundations of the Eiffel Tower starts in Paris, France
The first railway in China goes into operation.
Argentina is the first country to recognize the abolition of the monarchy in Brazil.
Thomas A. Edison finishes construction of the first motion picture studio in West Orange, New Jersey.
New Zealand becomes the first country in the world to grant women the right to vote.
Brothers Charles and Frank Duryea drive the first gasoline-powered motorcar in America on public roads in Springfield, Massachusetts.
The first professional American football game is played, in Latrobe, Pennsylvania
The Boston subway opens, becoming the first underground metro in North America.
Belo Horizonte, the first Brazilian Planned City, is created.
The first electric bus becomes operational in New York City.
The first zeppelin flight is carried out over Lake Constance near Friedrichshafen, Germany.
Funeral of Queen Victoria in London.
The first Nobel Prize ceremony is held in Stockholm on the fifth anniversary of Alfred Nobel's death.
An aeroplane of Alberto Santos-Dumont takes off at Bagatelle in France and flies 60 meters (200 feet). This is the first officially recorded powered flight in Europe.
Louis Bleriot is the first man to fly across the English Channel in a heavier-than-air craft
The first official air mail flight takes place from Allahabad, India to Naini, India
RMS Titanic strikes an iceberg in the northern Atlantic Ocean at 11:40 pm
RMS Titanic sinks at 2:20 a.m., taking with her the lives of more than 1,500 people.
Italy returns the ''Mona Lisa'' to France
World War I: German forces occupy Brussels
Battle of the Falkland Islands, between Doveton Sturdee and Maximilian von Spee squadrons.
In Browning, Montana, the temperature drops from +6.7¬∞C to -48.8¬∞C (44¬∞F to -56¬∞F) in one day, the greatest change ever on record for a 24-hour period.
World War I: Finland forms an alliance with Germany.
World War I: Austria-Hungary surrenders to Italy.
The first commercial radio station in the United States, 8MK (WWJ), begins operations in Detroit, Michigan
The Treaty of Lausanne, settling the boundaries of modern Turkey, is signed in Switzerland by Greece, Bulgaria and other countries that fought in the First World War
New York City becomes the largest city in the world
Charles Lindbergh makes the first solo non-stop trans-Atlantic flight, from New York to Paris
The first Japanese metro line, the Ginza Line in Tokyo, opens.
The first ever east-west transatlantic aeroplane flight takes place from Dublin, Ireland, to Greenly Island, Canada
The first diesel engine automobile trip is completed (Indianapolis to New York City).
The first frozen foods of Clarence Birdseye go on sale in Springfield, Massachusetts
Revolution of 1930: Get√∫lio Dornelles Vargas takes power in Brazil.
Picasso completes his painting ''Guernica''
Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact: Adolf Hitler and Joseph Stalin agree to divide Europe between Germany and the Soviet Union
Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union agree on a division of Poland after their invasion.
The very first McDonald's restaurant opens in San Bernardino, California
WWII: Operation Ariel begins: Allied troops start to evacuate France
WWII - Battle of Normandy: ''Operation Overlord'', commonly known as D-Day, commences with the landing of 155,000 Allied troops on the beaches of Normandy in France
The Holocaust: The evacuation of Auschwitz concentration camp begins.
Brazilian forces liberate the town of Montese, Italy, from German forces.
WWII: Atomic bombing of Hiroshima, with a bomb codenamed Little Boy
The novel ''Animal Farm'' by George Orwell is first published by Fredric Warburg in London.
WWII ends: The final official surrender of Japan is accepted by the Supreme Allied Commander, General Douglas MacArthur
Women's suffrage: Women are allowed to vote in France for the first time.
Get√É∆í√Ç¬∫lio Vargas resigns as the president of Brazil.
Assembly of the world's first general purpose electronic computer, the Electronic Numerical Integrator and Computer (ENIAC)
The first London chapter of Alcoholics Anonymous is founded.
The 1948 Summer Olympics begin in London, the first since the 1936
The first Volkswagen Beetle to arrive in the United States, a 1948 model, is brought to New York
The North Atlantic Treaty is signed in Washington, D.C., creating the NATO defense alliance.
The Great Flood of 1951 reaches its highest point in Northeast Kansas
King George VI of the United Kingdom dies aged 56 after a long illness. He is succeeded by his daughter Princess Elizabeth
The first successful surgical separation of Siamese twins is conducted in Mount Sinai Hospital, Cleveland, Ohio
Juan Fangio, the Argentine driver for German Grand Prix team Mercedes-Benz, makes a new fastest lap of the Silverstone Circuit
The Brazilian president, Getulio Vargas, commits suicide after being accused of involvement in a conspiracy to murder a Brazilian Air Force officer
The largest Live Television Broadcast at the time showed the preview of Disneyland Theme Park in Anaheim, California
The Ibirapuera Planetarium (the first in the Southern Hemisphere) is inaugurated in the city of S√£o Paulo, Brazil
The first known human with HIV dies in the Congo
NASA announces its selection of 7 military pilots to become the first U.S. astronauts
The first CERN particle accelerator becomes operational in Geneva, Switzerland
Construction of the Berlin Wall begins, restricting movement between East Berlin and West Berlin
The first episode of the BBC television series ''Doctor Who'' is broadcast in the United Kingdom.
The Beatles arrive from England at New York City's JFK International Airport
Pablo Picasso paints his fourth ''Head of a Bearded Man''.
Tokyo officially becomes the largest city of the world
Vietnam War: The first contingent of Australian combat troops arrives in South Vietnam.
Vietnam War: The first 4,000 101st Airborne Division paratroopers arrive in Vietnam
Uniform daylight saving time is first observed in most parts of North America.
In New York City, Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. makes his first public speech on the Vietnam War.
Guerrilla leader Che Guevara and his men are captured in Bolivia.
Apollo program: NASA launches ''Apollo 7'', the first manned Apollo mission
In Toulouse, France the first Concorde test flight is conducted.
Apollo program: ''Apollo 10'' returns to Earth, after a successful 8-day test of all the components needed for the upcoming first manned Moon landing.
Apollo program: ''Apollo 11'' (Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, Michael Collins) lifts off toward the first landing on the Moon.
The ''Apollo 11'' astronauts return from the first successful Moon landing
Elvis Presley begins his first concert tour since 1958 in Phoenix, Arizona.
The North Tower of the World Trade Center is topped out at 1,368 feet (417 m), making it the tallest building in the world.
Munich Massacre: Eleven Israeli athletes at the 1972 Summer Olympics in Munich are murdered
Elvis Presley's concert in Hawaii. The first worldwide telecast by an entertainer watched by more people than watched the Apollo moon landings.
The first handheld cellular phone call is made by Martin Cooper in New York City
Soyuz 12, the first Soviet manned flight since the Soyuz 11 tragedy in 1971, is launched.
The name Micro-soft is used by Bill Gates in a letter to Paul Allen for the first time
The first known outbreak of Ebola virus occurs in Yambuku, Zaire.
The first oil through the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System reaches Valdez, Alaska.
Louise Brown, the world's first test tube baby, is born in Oldham, Manchester, UK.
Pope John Paul II is shot and nearly killed by Mehmet Ali, a Turkish gunman
In Utah, a 61-year-old retired dentist Barney Clark becomes the first person to receive a permanent artificial heart
Vanessa Lynn Williams becomes the first African-American to be crowned Miss America, in Atlantic City, New Jersey
The first democratic elections in Argentina after 7 years of military rule are held.
Tancredo Neves is elected president of Brazil by the Congress, ending the 21-year military rule
El Descanso bombing: A terrorist bombing attributed to the Islamic Jihad Organization in the ''El Descanso'' restaurant near Madrid, Spain
The Chernobyl disaster: A mishandled safety test at the Chernobyl Nuclear Power Plant in Pripyat, Ukrainian SSR killed at least 4056 people
Cold War: Ronald Reagan and Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev meet in Reykjavik, Iceland, to continue discussions about scaling back their missile arsenals in Europe
Cold War: Schabowski accidentally states in live broadcast press conference that new rules for traveling from East Germany to West Germany will be put in effect immediately
Brazil holds its first free presidential election since 1960
Apartheid: In South Africa, President F.W. de Klerk allows the African National Congress to legally function again and promises to free Nelson Mandela
The 1990 FIFA World Cup begins in Italy.
West Germany defeats Argentina 1-0 to win the 1990 FIFA World Cup.
Gulf War: Iraq invades Kuwait, eventually leading to the Gulf War.
Collapse of the Soviet Union: Azerbaijan declares independence from Soviet Union.
Gulf War: Two laser-guided smart bombs destroy an underground bunker in Baghdad, killing hundreds of Iraqis
Collapse of the Soviet Union: Estonia declares its independence from the Soviet Union
Collapse of the Soviet Union: Latvia declares its independence from the Soviet Union.
Collapse of the Soviet Union: Azerbaijan declares independence from Soviet Union.
Turkey's worst coal mine disaster leaves 263 dead near Zonguldak.
The Assembly of Bosnia and Herzegovinaproclaims independence from the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia.
Microsoft releases Windows 3.1
NASA launches the Space Shuttle ''Endeavour'' on a mission to repair an optical flaw in the Hubble Space Telescope.
Nelson Mandela is inaugurated as South Africa's first black president.
Brazil wins the 1994 FIFA World Cup, defeating Italy by 3-2 in penalties (full time 0-0).
Microsoft releases Windows 95.
Dolly the sheep, the first mammal to be successfully cloned from an adult cell, is born at the Roslin Institute in Midlothian, Scotland.
The 1996 Summer Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia, United States, begin.
A Brazilian TAM Fokker airliner crashes into a densely populated area of S√£o Paulo, killing 103.
Pablo Picasso's ''T√™te de Femme'' is stolen from a London gallery (recovered a week later).
France beats Brazil 3-0 in the World Cup final, with the first two goals scored by Zinedine Zidane.
Google, Inc. is founded in Menlo Park, California, by Stanford University Ph.D. candidates Larry Page and Sergey Brin.
Kosovo War: Kosovo's main border crossings are closed by Serbian forces to prevent ethnic Albanians from leaving.
The Woodstock 99 festival is held in New York.
Sony launches a PlayStation 2 in Tokyo.
The ''Russian submarine K-141 Kursk'' sinks in the Barents Sea, resulting in the deaths of all 118 men on board.
The 2000 Summer Olympics are held in Sydney, Australia.
Almost 3,000 are killed in the 9/11 attacks at the World Trade Center in New York City
U.S. invasion of Afghanistan: In eastern Afghanistan, Operation Anaconda begins.
The funeral of Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother takes place in Westminster Abbey, London.
In Nigeria, more than 100 are killed at an attack aimed at the Miss World contestants.
The Cricket World Cup begins in South Africa.
An earthquake in the Boumerd¬®s region of northern Algeria kills 2,200
The largest hailstone ever recorded falls in Aurora, Nebraska
A rocket explosion kills 21 at the Brazilian rocket complex in Alc√¢ntara, Brazil, due to the premature ignition of a solid rocket booster.
Facebook was founded at Cambridge, Massachusetts.
The first ever reported South Atlantic hurricane makes landfall in South Brazil in the state of Santa Catarina
The largest expansion of NATO to date takes place, allowing Bulgaria, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, Romania, Slovakia and Slovenia into the organization
The 30th G8 summit takes place over the next 2 days on Sea Island, in Georgia, USA
After six days of intense battles, the Iraqi town of Fallujah is fully occupied by U.S. forces.
The world's tallest bridge, the Millau bridge over the River Tarn in the Massif Central mountains, France, is opened by President Jacques Chirac
North Korea announces that it possesses nuclear weapons as a protection against the hostility it feels from USA
The Kyoto Protocol goes into effect, without the support of the United States and Australia
The largest UN World Summit in history is held in New York City
The United Nations Climate Change Conference is held in Montreal, Quebec.
Surgeons in France carry out the first human face transplant
The 2006 Winter Olympics are held in Turin, Italy
A swan with Avian Flu is discovered in Cellardyke in Fife, Scotland (the first case in the United Kingdom)
The 2006 FIFA World Cup begins in Germany
The United Nations Climate Change Conference is held at Nusa Dua in Bali, Indonesia
Iran opens its first space center and launches a rocket into space
The 2008 Summer Olympics take place in Beijing, China
An earthquake measuring 6.6 magnitude kills at least 65 in Kyrgyzstan
The 2008 Santa Catarina floods in Santa Catarina, Brazil kill 126
The second G-20 summit, involving state leaders meets in London, focusing an ongoing global financial crisis.
The Supreme Court of Honduras orders the arrest and exile of President Manuel Zelaya
Bolivia becomes the first South American country to declare the right of indigenous people to govern themselves
The International Olympic Committee awards the 2016 Summer Olympics to Rio de Janeiro
The tallest man-made structure to date, the Burj Khalifa in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, is officially opened
The 2010 Winter Olympics are held in Vancouver and Whistler, Canada.
An 8.8-magnitude earthquake occurs in Chile, triggering a tsunami over the Pacific and killing 497
The 2010 FIFA World Cup is held in South Africa, and is won by Spain
An earthquake and consequent tsunami off the coast of Sumatra, Indonesia, kills over 400 people and leave hundreds missing
Flooding and mudslides in the Brazilian state of Rio de Janeiro kill more than 480
Opening ceremony of the 2012 Summer Olympics begins in London
